item.title: Internal: Uberflip V1 vs. V2 Hubs explained
item.description:
Uberflip uses 2 different frontend technologies to render Hubs for visitors. This article outlines the difference between the two front end versions and what this may mean for you.

 

What is Hub frontend V1 vs. V2? 

The Hub frontend is the technology that powers the visitor-facing elements of all Uberflip Hubs. This includes basically everything in your Hub that your visitors can see and interact with: the home page, the navigation menu, Stream and Item pages, Item and CTA tiles, and so on.

There are currently two versions of this technology:

  • Front End V1 was the original version of Uberflip's Hub front end technology. It was originally developed in 2012, when Uberflip first launched the Hubs product. 
  • Front End V2 is Uberflip's next-generation Hub front end framework, which was redesigned from the ground up. Front end V2 brings essential additions such as:
    • Built in accessibility features
    • Improved page speed 
    • Improved SEO performance

The differences between these two versions are almost entirely "under the hood": while Front End V2 Hubs are more accessible and faster, they are designed to look and feel just like Front End V1 Hubs.

 

What are the benefits of V2 over V1?

Increased page performance and improved SEO are both benefits of V2 Hubs, but most important is the accessibility upgrades. 

Uberflip is committed to growing our accessibility capabilities, so you can deliver great content experiences to everyone. Uberflip uses Website Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) to inform our accessibility choices.

Website Content Accessibility Guidelines were developed as part of a global initiative that aims to make online content more accessible for everyone. This includes the use of screen readers, tabbed browsing, closed captioning, and more. To align with these standards, Front End V2 brings: 

  • Aria labels
  • Screen reader compatibility 
  • All necessary accessibility tags 
  • Accessibility features like skip links and improved tab abilities
  • Improved page flow structure 
  • And more

Accessible content benefits everyone, including you and your Hubs. Webpages created within the Uberflip platform need to be at minimum Double-A compliant. 

V2 Hubs are also required to access some newer functionalities that aren't available on V1 Hubs. 

 

Is there anything on V1 that isn't included in V2 Hubs?

The following legacy features are not supported on V2 hubs. These are older, low use features that are being phased out:

  • Metrics (legacy)
  • Left-side navigation Hub menu (only top nav is supported in V2 Hubs)
  • Hubs Lab - Sticky Footer 
  • Hubs Lab - Hide banner on iframe embed
  • Hubs Lab - Dark Theme
  • Item Tile share links
  • AddThis sharing integration

 

Do I need to upgrade my V1 Hubs?

Upgrading is not required. If you’re currently using any V1 Hubs, you're free to continue using those Hubs as they are. 

As of March 2020, all newly created Hubs run on Front End V2. So if all of your Hubs were created after that—you’re already living in the future.

 

How can I know which Hub version I use?

If you want to check which version of the Uberflip Hub Front End your Hub is running, use the following method:

  1. In any browser, visit your hub's home page
  2. Right-click anywhere, then click on View Source or View Page Source (depending on your browser) to view the page's source HTML
  3. When you're viewing the page source code, press Ctrl+F (Cmd+F on Mac) and search for <body
  4. In the source HTML, the string <body should be highlighted (there should only be one result) Take a look at the text that appears after this string to identify your Hub Front End version:
    • If you see <body class="hub-page, your Hub is running Front End V1:
    • If you see <body id="uf-hub-page", your Hub is running Front End V2:

item.title: Internal: UFA Acquisition Channel Troubleshooting Tools
item.description:
Use these tools to understand and troubleshoot how Uberflip Analytics assigns Acquisition Channels to incoming web traffic.

Introduction

Acquisition channels are broad groupings of related traffic types, e.g. traffic from search engines like Google and Bing would be classified as "organic", traffic from sites like Facebook and Twitter would be classified as "social", etc.

As of January 2023, Uberflip Analytics uses a new method (algorithm) to assign acquisition channels to incoming web traffic. The new algorithm looks at a variety of factors, in a particular order, to assign one of the following acquisition channels to all visits:

  • paid-display
  • paid-search
  • paid-social
  • social
  • organic
  • email
  • display
  • referrer
  • other
  • direct

In some cases, customers may contact us asking why Uberflip Analytics assigned a particular acquisition channel to a given visit.

This article contains the following tools to help you address these inquiries:

  • A flowchart that explains how Uberflip Analytics assigns acquisition channels 
  • A table that contains the keywords referenced in the flowchart and their corresponding channels
  • An internal report that allows you to review specific traffic and the factors that were used to assign an acquisition channel to that traffic

Tool: Algorithm Flowchart

What it is

A flowchart which explains the overall method and order used by the algorithm to assign acquisition channels to traffic.

How to use

To view the flowchart, either click on the link below, or click on the attachment at the bottom of this article.

UFA Flowchart - Understand how Acquisition Channels are set

  1. Begin at Start
  2. Follow the decision branches to understand which factors lead to a particular channel being chosen
  3. Read and follow the appropriate use guidelines below before communicating with the customer

Appropriate use guidelines

Warning: Confidential — Internal Use Only

The flowchart is strictly for internal use only.

Do NOT share the flowchart, or any specific details from the flowchart, with customers or anyone else outside of Uberflip.

The flowchart linked from this page contains confidential information about a proprietary Uberflip algorithm. The algorithm represents a potential competitive advantage over Uberflip's competitors. As a result, specific details about the algorithm and how it works must be kept secret.

When using the flowchart, please follow these Dos and Don'ts to ensure appropriate usage:

✓ DO refer to the flowchart to learn how UFA assigns acquisition channels, so that you are equipped to respond to customer inquiries.

Example: A customer contacts you with a question about UFA acquisition channels. Do refer to the flowchart to help you figure out the answer.

✘ DON'T share the flowchart itself.

Example: When providing your explanation to the customer, don't show them the flowchart as you explain the answer (e.g. via screen sharing) — and definitely don't send them the flowchart file (or even screenshots of it).

✓ DO use your understanding of the algorithm to provide the customer with just enough information to answer their specific question.

Example: When you have determined why a particular acquisition channel was selected, do focus on specific details that explain the choice (e.g. "Looking at this traffic, I can see there was a parameter from Marketo attached to the URL. Those would usually only appear on links in emails sent from Marketo so that's most likely why it was set as email.")

✘ DON'T provide more information about the algorithm than necessary to answer the specific question.

Example: As part of your explanation, don't share details about the way the algorithm works generally (e.g. "So we first look at UTM source, and then UTM medium, and we compare those to a list of known keywords. And if we don't find a match there, we go and look at the referrer domain...")

Tool: UTM Parameter Keyword List

What it is

A list of keywords that the algorithm looks for in the values of the UTM Medium and UTM Source parameters, along with the acquisition channel the keyword is associated with (see the Check  UTM Medium & Source for recognized keyword of the flowchart).

How to use

One of the mechanisms the algorithm uses to assign an acquisition channel is to check the UTM Medium and UTM Source parameters (if present) to see if the values of these parameters match a known keyword that has a known association with a channel.

The keywords and their corresponding channels are listed in this table:

UTM Parameter Keyword Acquisition Channel
cpc Paid-Display
ppc Paid-Display
paid Paid-Display
advertis Paid-Display
partnership Paid-Display
sponsorship Paid-Display
placement Paid-Display
adword Paid-Display
google Paid-Search
bing Paid-Search
duckduckgo Paid-Search
yahoo Paid-Search
social Social
linkedin Social
facebook Social
fb Social
twitter Social
youtube Social
instagram Social
mail email
blog Display
display Display
cpm Display
banner Display
bot Display
embed Display
cpa Referrer
cpp Referrer
content Referrer
cpv Referrer
website Referrer
other Other
direct Direct

Note

The algorithm will consider a keyword a match if it matches part of a UTM parameter value. For example, ?utm_medium=advertising and ?utm_medium=advertisment would both be a match for the keyword advertis.

Typically, customers will want to understand which UTM values they should use to ensure that traffic is correctly assigned to the desired channel. To help them choose, use the table above:

  1. Refer to the flowchart to understand how the algorithm matches UTM Medium and UTM Source parameters to keywords
    • For example, most channels can be assigned based on a keyword match in either UTM parameter, but the Paid-Display, Paid-Search and Paid-Social channels require specific combinations of keywords to be assigned
  2. Review the table to understand which keywords will lead to which channel being assigned
  3. Use the keywords from the table above to suggest appropriate keywords to the customer based on their use case
    • For example, if the customer wants to ensure a link used in a Google ad is assigned to the channel Paid-Search, they should set the UTM parameters as: ?utm_medium=paid&utm_source=google

Tool: Channel Debugging Report

What it is

A report that shows all traffic (by default for the past 2 days) by session ID, along with the UFA-selected acquisition channel, and the factors taken into consideration to assign the acquisition channel (UTM source/medium, URL parameters, referrer domain).

How to use

You can find the internal report to review and troubleshoot acquisition channel assignments for specific traffic here:

Acquisition Channel Debugging Report

  1. Use the filter controls to narrow down the traffic shown to the desired scope, e.g. by account/Hub, date etc
  2. Locate the traffic for which you want to understand how the acquisition channel was chosen and review the values under the UTM Medium, UTM Source, Referring Domain and URL Parameters columns
  3. Reference the flowchart to understand how the assigned acquisition channel was determined by the algorithm

item.title: OnBrand - Ticket and Escalation Process
item.description:
Learn how to get help from Uberflip's OnBrand team for customer OnBrand work, and how to escalate urgent issues.

 

Before you begin

  • The processes described in this article are intended for use by any internal Uberflip team.

 

Getting help from the OnBrand team

How do I get support for a customer issue pertaining to Onbrand?

Uberflip's OnBrand team is responsible for all branding and design features of a hub that are not achieved via the platform's settings.  This includes new implementations and updates to existing hubs.

What are OnBrand tickets, and why are they important?

Uberflip's OnBrand team receives a lot of requests for help. To manage all of these requests, and to ensure nothing is missed or forgotten, we use a ticket system in Zendesk. In this system, every request for work is represented by its own ticket.

Using tickets allows us to:

  • Keep track of all requests, so that we can make sure that all requests get a response.
  • Centralize communication related to a request, so that everyone involved has a definitive record of what's been discussed, and so we can ensure that every aspect of the request is addressed.
  • Prioritize requests, so that we can handle the most urgent requests first (but without forgetting about requests that are less urgent, but equally important).
  • Guarantee a response within a specific timeframe. In fact, an Onbrand ticket is the only way to get help from the Onbrand team that has a Service Level Agreement (SLA) behind it.  There is a 4-hour SLA for a first-response out to the customer.
  • Measure the business, so we know how well the OnBrand team is performing, and whether the business is growing.

In short: tickets help the OnBrand team to help you and our customers.

 

Do I really have to submit tickets for OnBrand assistance?

We know that submitting a ticket to OnBrand seems inconvenient compared to just sending a Slack message. But without tickets, things can get missed or lost altogether — and that makes everyone unhappy (especially customers!). This is why we ask you to submit Onbrand tickets: they allow the OnBrand team to do the best possible job for both you and the customer.

 

Where do OnBrand tickets live?

We use Zendesk as our system of record for managing tickets for both product Support and Onbrand. That's why you might also see tickets referred to as "Zendesk tickets".

While it is mainly the Support and OnBrand teams that works in Zendesk, all members of the Customer Experience department also have access to this system to check on the status of open support tickets.

 

Who can submit an Onbrand ticket?

Tickets are to be submitted directly from customers using the Support portal.  Some exceptions to this can be made for bugs identified in-house or for escalations.

 

How does a customer submit an Onbrand ticket?

There are two methods for customers to submit tickets:

  • Email: support@uberflip.com.  Support will intercept these and transfer to OnBrand's ticket queue.   This may have a slight delay in getting to Onbrand's queue for visibility.
  • Help Portal (preferred because it goes straight to the OnBrand queue): https://help.uberflip.com (click on Submit a Request > OnBrand Request)

How does an Uberflip team member submit a ticket?

Follow the the process for submitting an OnBrand support ticket as an Uberflip team member below.

Process: Submit an OnBrand support ticket

Use this process to submit a new ticket.

  1. Log in to Zendesk at https://help.uberflip.com/
  2. Click on +Add, then New > Ticket:
  3. Fill in the fields on the left side:
    • Requester: This is the customer's contact information (the person OnBrand should correspond with about the issue).  This is a very critical piece of information.  Take the time to get this one correct.
    • CCs: Can be added for others who should be copied on all correspondence on this ticket.
    • Form: Select Onbrand Form
    • Customer Name: Enter the company name
    • Account ID: Enter the Uberflip account ID (this is helpful for multi-account customers)
    • Hub ID or Hub URL: Enter the hub ID or URL (also helpful for multi-hub accounts so we can make sure we're looking at the right one)
    • Priority: See Setting priority below.
  4. Describing the issue/request -
    1. If you do not want the customer to be able to see your note, use the Internal Note option (make sure the field turns yellow), then enter a detailed explanation of the issue.  You would use this option if you've flagged a bug internally and the customer may not be aware of it.
    2. If you do want the customer to see your message in the Zendesk ticket, use the Pubic Reply tab
  5. Click on Submit as New to finish submitting the ticket.

 

Internal Note (will only be visible to internal users of Zendesk):

 

Public Reply (The customer contacts included on the ticket will receive this message):

 

 

Setting severity and priority

When you submit an Onbrand support ticket, you will need to specify the priority of the issue:

Priority is a measure of how important an issue is from a business and customer impact perspective which determines the level of escalation.

The Onbrand team relies on these fields to efficiently prioritize requests, so setting the correct priority for your ticket is very important.

For each field, you will need to choose from a list of options. Each of the available options has a definition that outlines its criteria. You can find these below:

 

Priority level definitions

Use this table to help you choose the appropriate priority level for your request ticket. Remember: priority tells us how much the customer cares about this issue (regardless of how broken the affected system is).

Priority Definition
1 - Urgent

Immediate business impact affecting multiple internal initiatives / business objectives. Data loss. Urgently time sensitive issues (i.e. needs to be addressed right now - should be accompanied by an escalation via the #onbrand-escalations channel in Slack).
2 - High

Blockers/issues that cause major impact to the client’s continued use of the platform or affect other business objectives with no workaround. Highly time sensitive issues (2-3 business days).
3 - Normal

Standard support issue or inquiry. This should be used for the majority of tickets.
4 - Low

General questions about the platform. Issues with very little to no impact.

Common mistakes

Here are some common mistakes to avoid when submitting an Onbrand ticket:

  • Filing the ticket under your own name, instead of the customer's:
    When you submit the ticket, remember to set the customer as the Requester, not yourself! We need this information to contact the client, and if it's missing, this causes delays.
  • Creating a ticket by forwarding a customer's email to support@uberflip.com:
    This sets you (not the customer) as the Requester, and could cause delays in responding to the customer. In addition, often the customers email is not clear, or worse, consists of a long thread of messages.  Instead, please follow the instructions above for submitting a ticket and paste the customer's email into the Internal Note field when you create the ticket according to the process above or use the portal.
  • Not providing any or enough details about the issue: If the ticket doesn't have enough information for us to go on, all we can do is ask you or the customer for the missing information. This typically results in back and forth that wastes time and is frustrating for the customer. To avoid this, please include as many details as possible, i.e. which Hub and/or specific assets are affected, steps to reproduce the issue, etc. You should also:
    • Verify that the issue exists as described by the client
    • Describe the issue clearly and concisely in the ticket
    • Provide a clear indication of the impact this issue is having for your client

As a general rule, a good ticket is one where OnBrand can get back to the customer with a first response directly, and does not have to follow up with you first.

 

Escalating Onbrand tickets

What does it mean to escalate an OnBrand ticket?

From time to time, issues come up that are extremely urgent, and need to be resolved as soon as possible. For these issues, you have the ability to escalate an Onbrand ticket.

When you ask for an Onbrand ticket to be escalated, you are effectively telling the OnBrand team:

"I want you to drop what you're doing and work on this ticket ahead of all other ongoing activities."

Is there anything I need to consider before I request an escalation?

While tickets legitimately need to be escalated in some situations, always remember that escalations come at a cost:

  • Escalations are disruptive: they can have a negative effect on productivity due to shifting priorities.
  • Escalations are expensive: they typically require expensive resources (management, developers, etc.) to take time away from their ongoing work to focus exclusively.
  • Escalations result in poor customer experiences: an escalation makes one customer happy, but potentially makes all other customers unhappy because work on their issues has to be delayed.

Before you escalate a ticket, keep the impact in mind and use your judgment to make sure that the situation really does call for an escalation. In some cases, this might mean reaching out to a customer to manage their expectations instead of escalating the ticket.

When should I escalate an OnBrand ticket?

There are many situations where an escalation is warranted, and a comprehensive list of these situations would be impractical and not very useful. As a result, the OnBrand team relies on you to use your judgment as to when an escalation is required.

Below are a few examples of situations that would call for an escalation:

  • The escalation is a bug
  • The issue is high impact such as a non-functional or missing menu/CTAs, or tiles that don't respond to click.
  • The issue could impact churn or revenue, e.g. the customer is at high risk for churning, or will not discuss renewal/upgrade until the issue is resolved.

How do I escalate an OnBrand ticket?

Follow the process for escalating a ticket below.

 

Process: Escalate an OnBrand ticket

Use this process to escalate an existing Onbrand ticket. Remember to use your judgment and make sure it's necessary to escalate the ticket before you proceed.

  1. In Slack, go to the #onbrand-escalations channel.
  2. Click on the Shortcuts button below the message box:

 

  1. Click on the OB Escalation Request shortcut:

 

2. Fill out the form with the details about the OnBrand ticket to be escalated, then click on Submit to post the escalation to the channel:

 

3. The Onbrand Development Coordinator (OBDC) Team Lead will review the escalation request. If it is deemed to be a valid escalation, the current OBDC on the escalated ticket, or the Team Lead will, acknowledge receipt and be in contact with you shortly after.

4. Continue to monitor the ticket until it has been resolved.

 

If you do not receive a response to your escalation within 30 minutes:

If required, reach out to the following individual Onbrand team members using Slack or email, in the following order:

  1. Team Lead, Onbrand Development Coordination
    • Aja Servais (Slack: aja.servais, Email: aja.servais@uberflip.com)
    • If no response:
  2. Director, Professional Services
    • Stacey Kimmett (Slack: stacey.kimmett, Email: stacey.kimmett@uberflip.com)

 

After hours escalations

The operating hours of the OnBrand team are currently 9 AM to 5 PM Eastern Time, Monday to Friday. Escalations are possible outside of these hours, and follow the normal procedure outlined above.

If you do not receive a response from OnBrand to your after hours escalation within a reasonable timeframe:

  1. Contact your manager. They will directly contact the Team Lead, OnBrand Coordination (Aja Servais), who will coordinate with the OnBrand team.  
  2. Continue to monitor the relevant Zendesk ticket for updates from the OBDC

Additional information

Quick reference: What to do when...

Here's a quick reference guide on what you should do in various common OnBrand-related situations:

When a customer... First, do this: Then, do this:
Asks about an ongoing OnBrand ticket (Zendesk)  Search Zendesk for the relevant OnBrand support ticket and check for updates If there is no recent update in the ticket or you aren't sure, @mention the assigned OBDC in the ticket's internal comments and ask for an update.
Tells you about a new issue they are experiencing with their hub's branding/design Search Zendesk to check if there is already a ticket open about this issue for the customer If there is no existing ticket for the customer, you can  submit one on their behalf but it is strongly encouraged to have customers submit their own tickets via the portal.
Asks for guidance on how to do something in a code block pertaining to custom features and you don't know the answer If you are not sure or comfortable answering code-related questions, that is ok! Ask the customer to submit their questions via the Zendesk portal and an OBDC will assist.
Wants to have new customizations/features added to a hub. Teach the customer how to submit requests directly to OnBrand via the portal Ask the customer to submit their questions via the Zendesk portal and an OBDC will be assigned to assist.
Wants to discuss a rebrand project or review mock-ups to confirm feasibility and/or scope Teach the customer how to submit requests directly to OnBrand via the portal Ask the customer to submit their questions via the Zendesk portal and an OBDC will be assigned to assist and arrange a call.

 

Using Slack for Onbrand support

Your fellow Uberflippers have a lot of knowledge about our product, our company, and our customers, and Slack can be a useful tool for accessing that knowledge. 

Important

Remember that Zendesk tickets are the only official way to get help from the OnBrand team, and the only one where you're guaranteed to get a response within a specific timeframe.

Members of the OnBrand Development Coordination (OBDC) team are typically present in the channels listed below:

 

Channel
 Used for

#onbrand-escalations

 Requesting that a specific ticket, for a specific customer, is given more attention, higher visibility, and a greater sense of urgency.
#onbrand General questions about onBrand process, turnaround times, feature examples etc.  Posting requests for specific work to be done in this channel will not be actioned.  

 

OnBrand Office Hours

OnBrand office hours are held daily Monday-Friday at 9:30am ET on a drop-in basis and everyone is welcome.  An OBDC and developer are in attendance to answer questions such as feasibility or scope of a customer request.

item.title: Internal: Logging in and out of Uberflip Marketplace
item.description:
While app.uberflip.com and the Uberflip Marketplace are intrinsically linked, they’re not the same thing. These are actually two different apps, with different sessions and cookies associated with each. 

Because of this you can be logged into Uberflip with one account, but logged into the Marketplace with another. This can cause problems and lost data. 

This article outlines the issues that may arise and best practices to avoid them. 

What’s happening?

When you log into Uberflip and head to the Marketplace, you’ll automatically be logged into the Marketplace with your Uberflip credentials. Simple!

But if you then log out of Uberflip, you will not be automatically logged out of the Marketplace. That’s because this is actually a different web app that’s being displayed within Uberflip.

As an Uberflip employee, it’s likely you’ll at times sign out of one Hub to log into another. But when you log into a new Hub, the Marketplace session persists from the previous log in, and won’t be overridden by logging into a new Hub.

So now you’re logged into a Hub with one set of credentials, but you’re logged into the Marketplace with another. Any changes you make in the Marketplace will apply to the Hub connected to that Marketplace session. 

Why is this an issue?

If you’ve logged into a new Hub, but Marketplace is still logged into a session from another Hub, any changes you make will apply to the Hub you were previously logged into.

This means that if you install, uninstall, update or edit a Marketplace app, you’re doing so for the previous Hub, not the one you’re currently logged into.

Example: You may want to delete an app from the Hub you’re currently working in, but if the Marketplace is still logged into a previous session, you would be deleting it from the previous Hub. This could cause broken functionality and lost data in that Hub. It can also cause confusion and frustration when expected changes don’t occur in the Hub you’re in. 

This can create serious issues if you were previously working in a client or public Uberflip Hub. We suggest not working in Marketplace when logged into the admin backend, unless proper precautions have been taken.  

How do I avoid issues?

To avoid cross-account issues, be sure you’re not carrying a Marketplace session between Hubs. Here are a few ways you can do this: 

  • Use an incognito/private browsing window for each Hub/Marketplace session you open
  • Clear your cookies (or just the specific Uberflip cookies) when logging in or out of an Uberflip Hub
  • Go to https://app.uberflip.com/marketplace and click Log out (top right) to end the current session before working within a new Hub session

item.title: Internal: Support and Escalation Processes
item.description:
Learn how to get help from Uberflip's Support team for customer issues, and how to escalate urgent issues.

 

Before you begin

  • The processes described in this article are intended for use by any internal Uberflip team.

 

Getting help from the Support team

How do I get support for a customer issue?

Uberflip's Support team is responsible for handling and resolving issues that our customers have with the Uberflip product. If you need help from the Support team, you can submit a support ticket.

What are support tickets, and why are they important?

Uberflip's Support team receives a lot of requests for help. To manage all of these requests, and to ensure nothing is missed or forgotten, we use a support ticket system. In this system, every request for help is represented by its own support ticket.

  • Keep track of all requests, so that we can make sure that all requests get a response.
  • Centralize communication related to a request, so that everyone involved has a definitive record of what's been discussed, and so we can ensure that every aspect of the request is addressed.
  • Prioritize requests, so that we can handle the most urgent requests first (but without forgetting about requests that are less urgent, but equally important).
  • Guarantee a response within a specific timeframe. In fact, a support ticket is the only way to get help from the Support team that has a Service Level Agreement (SLA) behind it.
  • Measure the business, so we know how well the Support team is performing, and whether the business is growing.
  • Maintain a historical record. This allows us to review past events at the individual customer, account level, and overall Uberflip company level; and serves as proof of interactions. It also provides opportunities to reduce duplication of efforts should the same issue arise again in the future.

In short: support tickets help the Support team to help you.

Do I really have to submit support tickets?

We know that submitting a support ticket seems inconvenient compared to just sending a Slack message. But without support tickets, things get missed or lost altogether — and that makes everyone unhappy (especially customers!). This is why we ask you to submit support tickets: they allow the Support team to do the best possible job for both you and the customer.

We use Zendesk as our system of record for managing support tickets. That's why you might also see support tickets referred to as "Zendesk tickets".

While it is mainly the Support team that works in Zendesk, all members of the Customer Experience department also have access to this system to check on the status of open support tickets.

Who can submit a support ticket?

Anyone who needs help from Uberflip Support. This could either be an Uberflip customer themselves, or any Uberflip team member who is looking for help on behalf of their customer.

How does a customer submit a support ticket?

There are three methods for customers to submit support tickets:

  • Help Portal: https://help.uberflip.com (click on Submit a Request)
  • Email: support@uberflip.com
  • Phone: 1-888-694-2946 (dial extension 2)

How does an Uberflip team member submit a support ticket?

Follow the the process for submitting a support ticket as an Uberflip team member below.

 

Process: Submit a support ticket

Use this process to submit a new support ticket.

  1. Log in to Zendesk at https://help.uberflip.com/
  2. Click on +Add, then New > Ticket:
  3. Fill in the fields on the left side:
    • Requester: Add the customer's contact information (the person Support should correspond with about the issue).  This is a very critical piece of information. Take the time to get this one correct.
    • CCs: Add yourself and any others who should be copied on all correspondence on this ticket.
    • Type: Select Question.
    • Severity: See Setting severity and priority below.
    • Feature: Select the part of Uberflip that the issue pertains to.
    • Priority: See Setting severity and priority below.
    • Ticket Source: Select the appropriate option as it relates to you (i.e. choose CSM if you are a CSM).
  4. On the right side, click on Internal Note (make sure the field turns yellow), then enter a detailed explanation of the issue.
  5. Click on Submit as New to finish submitting the ticket.

Setting severity and priority

When you submit a support ticket, you will need to specify the severity and priority of the issue:

Severity
A definition of the system impact of a particular issue.
"How broken is it?"
Priority
A measure of how important an issue is from a business and customer impact perspective.
“How much does the customer care?”

The Support team relies on these fields to efficiently prioritize requests, so setting the correct severity and priority for your ticket is very important.

For each field, you will need to choose from a list of options. Each of the available options has a definition that outlines its criteria. You can find these below:

Severity level definitions

Use this table to help you choose the appropriate severity level for your support ticket. Remember: severity tells us how broken the affected system is.

Each severity level is associated with a specific SLA (how quickly the Support team will respond to the customer), which is indicated. In addition, the table also shows the recommended priority level range for each severity level, along with the suggested CSM action.

Severity Definition SLA Priority CS Action
1 Production system down or imminent production mission critical failure, no workaround available. 1 hour 1 Engage immediately
2

Loss of key functionality which affects significant aspects of the business or operations.

 3 hours 2-3 Engage proactively
3

Issue impacting an isolated component that does not affect the ability of the system to perform in accordance with the documentation.

 6 hours 2-4 Monitor closely/engage if needed
4 Product is usable with limitations and workarounds – also a placeholder for general inquiries. 24 hours 2-4 Monitor
5

No system impact identified (e.g. feature tequests, user account requests, software delivery, status reports, etc.).

 48 hours 2-4 Monitor

Priority level definitions

Use this table to help you choose the appropriate priority level for your support ticket. Remember: priority tells us how much the customer cares about this issue (regardless of how broken the affected system is).

Priority Definition
1 - Urgent

Immediate business impact affecting multiple internal initiatives / business objectives. Data loss. Urgently time sensitive issues (i.e. needs to be addressed right now - should be accompanied by an escalation).
2 - High

Blockers/issues that cause major impact to the client’s continued use of the platform or affect other business objectives with no workaround. Highly time sensitive issues (2-3 business days).
3 - Normal

Standard support issue or inquiry. This should be used for the vast majority of tickets.
4 - Low

General questions about the platform. Issues with very little to no impact.

Common mistakes

Here are some common mistakes to avoid when submitting a support ticket:

  • Filing the ticket under your own name, instead of the customer's:
    When you submit the ticket, remember to set the customer as the Requester, not yourself! We need this information to contact the client, and if it's missing, this causes delays.
  • Creating a ticket by forwarding a customer email to support@uberflip.com:
    This also sets you (not the customer) as the Requester, and causes delays as we have to fix the ticket. In addition, often the customer's email is not clear, or worse, consists of a long thread of messages.  Instead, please follow the instructions above for submitting a ticket and paste the customer's email address into the Internal Note field when you create the ticket according to the process above.
  • Not providing any or enough details about the issue: If the ticket doesn't have enough information for us to go on, all we can do is ask you or the customer for the missing information. This typically results in back and forth that wastes time and is frustrating for the customer. To avoid this, please include as many details as possible, i.e. which Hub and/or specific assets are affected, steps to reproduce the issue, etc. You should also:
    • Verify that the issue exists as described by the client
    • Describe the issue clearly and concisely in the ticket
    • Provide a clear indication of the impact this issue is having for your client

As a general rule, a good support ticket is one where Support can get back to the customer with a first response directly, and does not have to follow up with you first.

 

Escalating support tickets

What does it mean to escalate a support ticket?

From time to time, issues come up that are extremely urgent, and need to be resolved as soon as possible. For these issues, you have the ability to escalate a support ticket.

When you ask for a support ticket to be escalated, you are effectively telling the Support team:

"I want you to drop what you're doing and work on this ticket ahead of all other ongoing activities."

Is there anything I need to consider before I request an escalation?

While tickets legitimately need to be escalated in some situations, always remember that escalations come at a cost:

  • Escalations are disruptive: they have a significant negative effect on productivity, often across multiple departments (Support, Product, Engineering, etc.), and force those involved to catch up on their regular duties after the escalation is resolved
  • Escalations are expensive: they typically require expensive resources (management, developers, etc.) to take time away from their ongoing work to focus exclusively
  • Escalations result in poor customer experiences: an escalation makes one customer happy, but potentially makes all other customers unhappy because work on their issues has to be delayed

Before you escalate a ticket, keep the impact in mind and use your judgment to make sure that the situation really does call for an escalation. In some cases, this might mean reaching out to a customer to manage their expectations instead of escalating the ticket.

When should I escalate a support ticket?

There are many situations where an escalation is warranted, and a comprehensive list of these situations would be impractical and not very useful. As a result, the Support team relies on you to use your judgment as to when an escalation is required.

Below are a few examples of situations that would call for an escalation:

  • The customer has made it clear to you that this issue is critical to their business objectives, so much so that it should take precedence over everything else currently being worked on.
  • The issue is time sensitive, e.g. the issue is preventing another process from being started or completed. In this case, it's important to indicate how time sensitive the issue is (one hour and one month require different levels or response).
  • The issue could impact churn or revenue, e.g. the customer is at high risk for churning, or will not discuss renewal/upgrade until the issue is resolved.

How do I escalate a support ticket?

Follow the process for escalating a support ticket below.

 

Process: Escalate a support ticket

Use this process to escalate an existing support ticket. Remember to use your judgment and make sure it's necessary to escalate the ticket before you proceed.

  1. In Slack, go to the #support-escalation channel.
  2. Click on the Workflows button at the top of the channel:
  3. Click on the Escalate Support Ticket shortcut from within the dropdown menu:
  4. Fill out the form with all relevant details about the support ticket to be escalated, including Business Impact, then click on Submit to post the escalation to the channel:
  5. In a follow-up message, @here and @mention the Support Representative who is assigned to the ticket currently.
  6. Support will review the escalation request. If it is deemed to be a valid escalation, the Support Representative will respond to your request for escalation within the #support-escalation channel and immediately proceed to work the ticket until a resolution is achieved.
  7. Continue to monitor the ticket until it has been resolved.

If you do not receive a response to your escalation within 30 minutes:

If required, reach out to the following individual Support team members using Slack or email, in the following order:

  1. Team Leads, Technical Support
    • Roshan Kathir (Slack: Roshan, Email: roshan.kathirgamasegaran@uberflip.com)
    • Tommy Bozikis (Slack: Tommy Bozikis, Email: tommy.bozikis@uberflip.com)
    • If no response:
  2. Director, Technical Support
    • Wes Ivany (Slack: Wes Ivany, Email: weston.ivany@uberflip.com)

Rejected escalations

If your escalation is rejected, follow these next steps:

  • Ensure all required information is present in the notification to #support-escalation.
  • Work with the Support Representative to ensure the business impact is well defined. Support must have a clear understanding of how the issue is affecting the customer before a ticket can be escalated.

Note also that Support will update the customer if required with appropriate information, regardless of whether the escalation is accepted.

After hours escalations

The operating hours of the Support team are currently 8 AM to 8 PM Eastern Time, Monday to Friday. (Excluding statutory holidays, which currently have operating hours of 9 AM to 5 PM Eastern Time) Escalations are possible outside of these hours, and follow the normal procedure outlined above.

If you do not receive a response from Support to your after-hours escalation within a reasonable timeframe:

  1. Contact your manager. They will directly contact the Director of Technical Support (Wes Ivany), who will coordinate with the Support team.
  2. Continue to monitor the relevant support ticket as well as the #support-escalation channel for updates.

Additional information

Quick reference: What to do when...

Here's a quick reference guide on what you should do in various common support-related situations:

When a customer... First, do this: Then, do this:
Asks about an ongoing support ticket (Zendesk) or development ticket (JIRA) Search Zendesk for the relevant support ticket and check for updates If there is no recent update in the ticket, @mention the assigned Support Representative in the ticket's internal comments and ask for an update
Tells you about a new issue they are experiencing with their Uberflip account Search Zendesk to check if there is already a ticket open about this issue for the customer If there is no existing support ticket for the customer, submit one on their behalf
Informs you about a defect in Uberflip's software Search Zendesk and JIRA to check if relevant tickets already exist If there is no existing ticket for the bug, submit a support ticket with a detailed description of the defect (do not create a JIRA ticket)
Asks for guidance on how to do something in Uberflip, and you don't know the answer Search our Knowledge Base for a relevant article If there is no relevant article, submit a support ticket (also, submit a documentation request)
Has in-depth questions about technical aspects of the Uberflip platform (e.g. integrations, SEO, etc.), and you don't know the answers Search our Knowledge Base for a relevant article If there is no relevant article, or our documentation doesn't answer the customer's questions, submit a support ticket (also, submit a documentation request)

 

Using Slack for support

Your fellow Uberflippers have a lot of knowledge about our product, our company, and our customers, and Slack can be a useful tool for accessing that knowledge. Here are a few support-related Slack channels you should know about, and what they're used for:

Important

Remember that support tickets are the only official way to get help from the Support team, and the only one where you're guaranteed to get a response within a specific timeframe.

Members of the Support team are typically present in the channels listed below, but their main job is to work on support tickets, so they may not always be available to respond on Slack.

Channel
 Used for
#success General questions about Uberflip's products, services, customers, and other topics related to Customer Experience.

#support-escalation

 Requesting that a specific ticket, for a specific customer, is given more attention, higher visibility, and a greater sense of urgency. This is the only channel actively monitored by Support.
#onbrand Questions about onBrand-related issues.

 

Submitting development (JIRA) tickets

In general, CSMs should not file JIRA tickets without consulting Support. This includes tickets for:

  • Product bugs
  • onBrand bugs
  • Operations issues

Support helps to refine these tickets, and ensures that Product/Engineering is getting the information they need to work on them, eliminating back-and-forth. In addition, all JIRA tickets filed on behalf of customers need to be attached to support tickets for communication purposes/visibility, and Zendesk users who are not part of the Support team do not have this ability.

If you need to submit a JIRA ticket on behalf of a customer, please make a note of it with details in a comment on an existing Zendesk ticket. If no ticket exists, please file a new Zendesk request with sufficient details to file a JIRA, including:

  • Customer information
  • Affected assets
  • Business impact to customer
  • Steps to reproduce

item.title: Internal Reference: Uberflip's Rate Limits
item.description:
An internal reference guide to the rate limits we set on our services.

Internal Use Only

The information in this article is for INTERNAL USE ONLY. It must not be shared outside of Uberflip. See here for further details.

 

About Uberflip's Rate Limits

What is a rate limit?

A rate limit is simply the maximum number of requests that a server will accept and process from a given IP address over a given time period. Uberflip sets and enforces rate limits to prevent our servers from becoming overloaded with requests, which can lead to service outages.

What happens when a rate limit is exceeded?

Rate limits are expressed as number of requests/time period. If an IP address sends requests to Uberflip's servers at a rate that exceeds the rate limit, the server will stop processing requests from that IP, and will instead return an error for each request (429 Too Many Requests). The server will continue to return errors instead of processing requests until the IP address reduces the rate at which it sends requests to below the rate limit.

How do Uberflip's rate limits work?

Rate limits apply to all Uberflip frontend services, which are publicly-accessible, Uberflip-operated services that can directly receive requests from users sent over the internet.

There are three categories of rate limits, high, medium, and low. Each Uberflip service falls into one of these categories, which defines the allowable rate limit for the services it contains. For example, services in the high category have a higher rate limit than those in the medium category, and so on.

Within each category, the specific rate limit applies per service and per unique IP address. This means that the number of requests any single IP address makes to Service A does not impact the number of requests that same IP address can make to Service B in the same category. Likewise, requests made by IP Address 1 to a service don't impact the requests that IP Address 2 can make to the same service.

 

Rate Limits

Each category consists of two types of rate limit: the average rate and the burst rate. The average rate is the maximum sustainable rate of requests, so exceeding this rate will cause you to be rate limited eventually. The burst rate is the absolute maximum rate of requests — you can hit this limit very briefly, but if you exceed this rate, you will be rate limited immediately.

Why are there two types of rate limit?

Uberflip's rate limiting mechanism employs a leaky bucket algorithm, in which incoming requests go into a "bucket" that "leaks" a particular rate:

  • When the bucket fills up, the rate limit has been exceeded. Any further requests will not go into the bucket (be processed), but will instead overflow (return an error).
  • The average rate is the rate at which the bucket leaks: as long as requests leak out of the bucket faster than they are dripping into the bucket, the bucket can never fill up.
  • The burst rate is the size of the bucket: if the rate at which requests drip into the bucket is the same as the size of the bucket, the bucket will fill up instantly. In practice, this means that the bucket can (very briefly) accept requests at a rate higher than the average, but this will lead to a "full bucket" situation much faster.
Category Average Rate Burst Rate Applies to
High 1200 requests/minute 2400 requests/minute High-demand services (API, UFA, etc.)
Medium 400 requests/minute 800 requests/minute Moderate-demand services (Uberflip front end)
Low 200 requests/minute 400 requests/minute Low-demand auxiliary services (certificate generation, etc.)

Why can't I share these rate limits with customers?

The rate limits outlined on this page are intended to protect the Uberflip platform from attacks that may destabilize it. In general, legitimate users (customers) should never come close to these limits.

In addition, these rate limits are experimental, and may be changed at any time if needed to ensure platform stability. Such adjustments may be made rapidly in response to emerging situations and without notice, so this article may not always reflect current rate limits.

For these reasons, please do not share any of the specific rate limits listed in this article with customers. Uberflip maintains a separate "public" rate limit that is documented here, and which you can provide to customers if requested.

item.title: Internal: Enable HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security) on Customer Domains
item.description:
Objective

Many security scanners will want HSTS enabled as a security best practice so we are likely to hear more and more customers requesting this feature be added to their Domains.

More on HSTS here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security

We can support HSTS today but we must enable on a domain by domain basis with a JIRA for OPS

 

Steps Required to Have HSTS enabled on Customer Domain(s)

  1. Ask the customer for some information we need to enabled HSTS:

    `max_age`: How long should browsers remember to automatically upgrade HTTP requests to HTTPS for this domain? Our default is 1 year, max is 2 years.
    `include_subdomains`    : Do they want browsers to automatically upgrade requests to subdomains of this domain? In most cases this won't matter because customers won't have subdomains of their hub domains.

    `preload`    : Do they want to eventually submit this domain to Google to include it in the HSTS preload list, so all Chrome users automatically get upgraded, without ever having seen the HSTS header
  2. Gather the above and create an OPS JIRA ticket specifying the domain(s) customer wants HSTS on.

 

Additional Notes

Enabling HSTS is not something that we enable by default on Domains once they get HTTPS enabled, as it could cause the Hub to lose traffic if they ever want to turn https off for some reason (e.g. they switch https on, find broken/mixed-content links, and switch it off again to fix them).  This is why we do on a request by request basis, initiated by customers.

item.title: [Internal resource] Remote Authentication: Integrate With Your Own Database
item.description:
What is Remote Authentication?

With this feature, you can protect your  Flipbooks by requiring a username and password (optional) to view. As with all Flipbook Security options, the set up is done at the Folder level and will apply to all Flipbooks belonging to that Folder.

This feature is intended to leverage your existing database of registered members or subscribers.

Rather than give us access to your database, if you are, or someone on your team is, able to write a simple script that is accessible over the web, the Flipbook reader can pass information (USERNAME and PASSWORD ONLY) via a POST to that script which can compare to your member database and return a response either indicating or preventing access. 

 

Remote Authentication Flow

 

Step 1: Access Security/Subscription Settings for the Folder and Choose the 'Remote Authentication' Use-Case

 

Step 2: Configure Login Screen and Script Settings

Referencing the image above, the fields are:

  1. Your remote login script to POST to:
    Enter the URL of your script residing on your host system.  This script will need to accept the Username and Password(optional) variables from the Flipbook login screen via a POST command,  compare them to your member database, and return a value indicating valid or invalid credentials.
  2. Success return value:
    Value your script returns to the Flipbook indicating valid or invalid credentials.  You have two approaches:
    1. Enter a string value in the text box our Application will look for to indicate valid credentials.  If the script returns a value matching that string, access will be granted.  All other values returned by the script will prevent access.
    2. Return user's ID.  Check this box and your script can return a username/user id corresponding to the credentials passed, which will allow the user to use Annotation tools on the Flipbook (if you've turned them on).   If using this option your script MUST return a value of 0 (zero), for invalid credentials.  Any returned value other than 0 will allow access (See this section below for an example script).
      • NOTE: Only the following characters will be recognized when returning values so please keep your responses within this character set:
         A-Z
         a-z
         0-9
         @
         .
         _
         -
         space
         /
         \
         ,
         :
         ;
         ! 
         =
  • Username field name:
    Enter the variable name in your script that will be assigned the username submitted from the login screen.
  • Password Field name (optional):
    Enter the variable name in your script that will be assigned the password (if required) submitted from the login screen.
  • Custom login Screen message (optional):
    Enter a message that you want to display to end users on the login screen.  You can use HTML/CSS/Javascript to get fancy!
  • Custom login Screen message (optional):
    Website for readers to navigate to for help in subscribing, logging in, or forgot password (optional).
  • Click "Save" button to apply settings/changes or click Close button to cancel.

 

Step 3: Allow for Previewing of Pages without Logging In

  1. Toggle on/off preview option and enter how many pages you would like non members to view without logging in.
  2. Click "Save" button to apply settings/changes or click Close button to cancel.

 

Reference Example

Let's take a fictional website "www.abc-co.com" as an example.

In this example:

  • ABC Co. has a database of users who can gain access to a specific title
  • ABC Co. creates a script that checks if a user has the necessary privileges
  • the remote login script is http://www.abc-co.com/loginscript.php
  • the username field name is uname
  • the password field name is pword
  • the string returned on success is welcome!
  • Our system POSTS a form that can be assumed to look like

    <form method="post" action=" http://www.abc-co.com/loginscript.php">
    <input type="text" name="uname" value="bob" />
    <input type="password" name="pword" value="bob123" />
    </form>
  • since user bob's password is "bob123", the script prints out "welcome!". Whatever is printed out by the script will be returned as the value, so make sure to not print out any html.

Our system will send the form using POST method (not GET) only from our backend, so you need not worry that anyone will ever see this script via client-side scripting.

An example php script: (for learning purposes only)

<?php
//open connection to database
mysql_connect(…);

//select your database
mysql_select_db(…);

$sql = "SELECT count(*) FROM `user_table` where username='" . $_POST['uname'] . "' AND password='" . $_POST['pword'] . "' LIMIT 1";

$result = mysql_query($sql);
$count = mysql_result($result,0);

if($count==1){
echo "welcome!";
} else {
echo "username/password combo not found";
}

?>

 

Return User's ID as Success Message

With the introduction of the Annotation Tools Widget comes the ability to return your users' ID instead of a generic success message. This will allow us to store information for your remote users on our system.

If "return user's ID" is selected as the Success return value, your script should be modified to output the user's ID or username IF the credentials were found to be valid. 

Your script should return a value of  "0"  (zero) if the query FAILS then our system will deny access to the user.

In the example above, the last code block could simply be changed to:

  • ...
    if($count==1){
    echo $_POST['uname'];
    } else {
    echo "0"; }
    ...
